presentation.title: Recreation: Hunting
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from ecosystem contributions toward hunting as a recreational activity
presentation.description: Values resulting from ecosystem contributions toward hunting as a recreational activity. Source models map the potential quality for habitat for harvestable species in a given part of the landscape. Flow models can be used to connect beneficiaries to areas where hunting can occur.

page.name: Assessment of natural areas for javelina hunting
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality areas for hunting, specifically for javelina (peccary), one of several important game species in southeast Arizona. The source model maps areas where javelina habitat is present, land that is accessible to the public, and areas where surface water is present as having high potential value for javelina hunting. By combining this map with information about recreational travel patterns and site selection, connections between recreational users and specific sites can be mapped, showing recreational use alongside other ecosystem services provided by recreational areas.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Assessment of natural areas for deer hunting
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality areas for hunting, specifically for deer (mule and whitetail), which are important game species in southeast Arizona. The source model maps areas where one or more deer species' habitat is present, land that is accessible to the public, and areas where surface water is present as having high potential value for deer hunting. By combining this map with information about recreational travel patterns and site selection, connections between recreational users and specific sites can be mapped, showing recreational use alongside other ecosystem services provided by recreational areas.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Assessment of natural areas for quail hunting
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality areas for hunting, specifically for quail (Gambels, Mearns', and scaled), which are important game species in southeast Arizona. The source model maps areas where one or more quail species' habitat is present, land that is accessible to the public, and areas where surface water is present as having high potential value for quail hunting. By combining this map with information about recreational travel patterns and site selection, connections between recreational users and specific sites can be mapped, showing recreational use alongside other ecosystem services provided by recreational areas.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Assessment of natural areas for dove hunting
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality areas for hunting, specifically for dove (mourning and white-winged), which are important game species in southeast Arizona. The source model maps areas where one or more dove species' habitat is present, land that is accessible to the public, and areas where surface water is present as having high potential value for dove hunting. By combining this map with information about recreational travel patterns and site selection, the connections between recreational users and specific sites can be mapped, showing recreational use alongside other ecosystem services provided by recreational areas.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Public access
page.title: Public access
page.description:
Areas with public access for recreational activities.

Role in models

Public access is a prerequisite for recreationists to engage in their activity of interest on a given parcel of land. Public access data are combined with other appropriate data to identify an area's suitability for the recreational activity of interest.

Representation

Data are categorical, and identify public land, private land with public access granted (e.g., nature preserves), or private land without public access.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Presence of surface water
page.title: Presence of surface water
page.description:
The presence of surface water from streams and springs.

Role in models

Surface water presence is an important input to birding source models for birding, wildlife viewing, and hunting, as surface water attracts wildlife of all kinds in arid and semiarid environments. Surface water presence data are combined with data on riparian quality (where available) to further estimate the quality of the surface water resource. These data are combined with public access data and species presence or richness in relevant source models for wildlife-based recreation.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of streams and springs.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Riparian condition class
page.title: Riparian condition class
page.description:
Riparian quality, rated from dry to wet, based on nine vegetation bioindicators sensitive to surface and groundwater conditions.

Role in models

Surface water presence data are combined with data on riparian quality (where available) to further estimate the quality of the surface water resource. These data are combined with public access data and species presence or richness in relevant source models for wildlife-based recreation.

Representation

Data are categorical, representing riparian condition class as described by Stromberg et al. (2006).

Source

Stromberg, J.C., et al. 2006. Status of the riparian ecosystem in the Upper San Pedro River, Arizona: Application of an assessment model. Environmental Monitoring and Assessment 115: 145-173.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Riparian, spring, or wetland quality
page.title: Riparian, spring, or wetland quality
page.description:
Presence of high, moderate, low quality, or no springs or surface water.

Role in models

Surface water presence data are combined with data on riparian quality (where available) to further estimate the quality of the surface water resource. These data are combined with public access data and species presence or richness in relevant source models for wildlife-based recreation. Where no condition class data are available the model currently assumes surface water to be ephemerally flowing.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Derived from surface water presence and riparian condition class data.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Dove habitat
page.title: Dove habitat
page.description:
Areas where mourning and/or white-winged dove (_Zenaida macroura_, _Z. asiatica_) are known or predicted to occur in the southwestern United States.

Role in models

The presence of dove habitat is a prerequisite for an area to support dove hunting. Habitat presence data are used as an input to the source model, along with public access and presence of surface water, to identify an area's suitability for dove hunting.

Representation

Data are categorical, and show the presence of habitat for one dove species, multiple dove species, or no dove species.

Source

Derived from Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Deer habitat
page.title: Deer habitat
page.description:
Areas where mule and/or white-tailed deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_, _O. virginianus_) are known or predicted to occur in the southwestern United States.

Role in models

The presence of deer habitat is a prerequisite for an area to support deer hunting. Habitat presence data are used as an input to the source model, along with public access and presence of surface water, to identify an area's suitability for deer hunting.

Representation

Data are categorical, and show the presence of habitat for one deer species, multiple deer species, or no deer species.

Source

Derived from Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Quail habitat
page.title: Quail habitat
page.description:
Areas where Gambels', Mearns', and/or scaled quail (_Callipepla gambelii_, _C. montezumae_, _C. squamata_) are known or predicted to occur in the southwestern United States.

Role in models

The presence of quail habitat is a prerequisite for an area to support quail hunting. Habitat presence data are used as an input to the source model, along with public access and presence of surface water, to identify an area's suitability for quail hunting.

Representation

Data are categorical, and show the presence of habitat for one quail species, multiple quail species, or no quail species.

Source

Derived from Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Javelina habitat
page.title: Javelina habitat
page.description:
Areas where javelina (_Pecari tajacu_) are known or predicted to occur in the southwestern United States.

Role in models

The presence of javelina habitat is a prerequisite for an area to support javelina hunting. Habitat presence data are used as an input to the source model, along with public access and presence of surface water, to identify an area's suitability for javelina hunting.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of potential javelina habitat.

Source

Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Southwest Regional GAP Analysis Project Animal Habitat Models.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Potential Dove hunting quality
page.title: Potential Dove hunting quality
page.description:
Suitability of different areas to support dove hunting.

Role in models

This is the output of the dove hunting source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas to support dove hunting, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to support dove hunting. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential hunting quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Potential deer hunting quality
page.title: Potential deer hunting quality
page.description:

Role in models

Representation

As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential hunting quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.

page.description:
Suitability of different areas to support quail hunting.

Role in models

This is the output of the quail hunting source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas to support quail hunting, based on relevant input data.

Representation

As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential hunting quality. This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.

page.name: Potential javelina hunting quality
page.title: Potential javelina hunting quality
page.description:
Suitability of different areas to support javelina hunting.

Role in models

This is the output of the javelina hunting source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas to support javelina hunting, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to support javelina hunting. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential hunting quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Population density
page.title: Population density
page.description:
Population density estimates can be used to map recreational use.

Role in models

Population density can be used along with recreational preference data, where available, to estimate the number of potential recreational uesrs for a given activity in a particular area. These data are thus used in the recreational use model.

Representation

Data are in physical units of persons per square kilometer.

Source

U.S. Census Bureau population estimates and TIGER block group files.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Census TIGER/Line Files.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Roads
page.title: Presence of roads
page.description:
Roads used to travel to recreational areas.

Role in models

Roads are used in the recreation flow model to determine the accessibility of recreational areas for potential users.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of roads.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Coucil.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Road travel capacity
page.title: Road travel capacity
page.description:
The type of road, which determines how quickly users can travel to potential recreation areas.

Role in models

These data identify the type of road (e.g., interstate, state highway, arterial, unpaved), which can be used by the recreation flow model to determine ease of access (e.g., travel cost to reach different sites).

Representation

Data are categorical by road type.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Coucil.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
page.credits:
Data source: Arizona Geographic Information Council.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Trails
page.title: Presence of trails
page.description:
Trails used by hikers, campers, and other recreational users.

Role in models

Trail data can be used in the recreation flow model to show recreational accessibility for certain parts of a recreation area. Without dedicated trail access, recreational use may be much lower. Areas with easily-accessible or high use trails offer a different visitor experience than more remote trails.

Representation

Data show the presence or absence of trails.

Source

Various public land management agencies.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Recreation flow
page.title: Recreational user flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
This map shows the movement of people toward recreation areas, based on transportation networks, recreational preferences, site quality, and a distance decay function.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Recreational use
page.title: Recreational use
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows the amount of recreational use actually occurring at a recreation area when accounting for demand and spatial flows of visitors.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Actual recreational users
page.title: Actual recreational users
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows the residential location of users who actually travel to sites via “recreation flows” to engage in recreational activities at source areas.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Transportation restricted use
page.title: Transportation restricted use
page.description:
*Inaccessible source maps* show source areas whose values are irrelevant to ecosystem service delivery, because of a lack of flow connections between sources and users.
For provisioning services, this is the portion of the value that must be subtracted from the total source map to define a maximum potential benefit for the users. For preventive services, it shows those areas that have no potential of producing damage because the flow dynamics prevent the carrier from impacting any significant user.
This map shows recreational areas whose current accessibility via transportation networks makes their use level more limited than their attractiveness alone would dictate.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Transportation restricted users
page.title: Transportation restricted users
page.description:
*Inaccessible use maps* shows potential users that cannot receive a service due to a lack of flow routes linking source and user locations.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows users too distant from a recreational site to benefit from it.
page.see-also: Recreation model details from the ARIES website
